node.title: Error when building a new app on HPC
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I recently installed MOOSE on an HPC using Miniforge. The installation was successful and all tests ran without errors. I can also create/compile/build new applications without errors. My problem is that when I add a new kernel (ADTri6StressDivergenceShell) and two material objects ( ADTri6ElasticityShell, ADTri6ShellStrain) to my application, I get an error in the last linking step! I am sure that I have correctly customized the new objects to my application as they worked on another MOOSE installation on another HPC. Please note that the error only occurs at the end of the build phase. The compiling log, the diagnostic script and the list of installed eviroment packages are listed below. I would be grateful if you could give me some advice or solution for this issue.
P.S. I tried using "git clean -xfd" but that did not solve the problem.
Best regards,
Kavan
Compiling log:
Not compiling MOOSE with NEML2 because NEML2_DIR is not a valid NEML2 checkout and/or libtorch is not enabled.

Hello
Did you remember to include #pragam once at the top of the header?
Can you share the source files for these two kernels?
The last thing I would try is save your work using git commit and then git clean -xfD at the head of the repo which will delete everything unsaved
Guillaume

Thank you @GiudGiud for your help. I found the main reason for the error! I was using Jupyterlab on this cluster to edit my codes and this caused the above linker error. However, the error disappears when I use VSCode!  I really don't know the reason, but I'm glad the problem is solved.
Thank you again,
Kavan

node.title: Issue with SuperLU when rebuilding PETSC
node.bodyText:
I am having trouble setting up Moose on a personal WSL machine. When I run ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh it eventually fails, saying that it is:
*********************************************************************************************
           UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS (see configure.log for details):
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          Error configuring SUPERLU_DIST with CMake
*********************************************************************************************

I am relatively new to bash and do not know how or where to access configure.log, any help would be appreciated.

Hello
For a personal WSL I would recommend these instructions instead:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
with those you dont have to run that script
Guillaume

Thank you, those are the instructions I originally followed, I am rebuilding as a troubleshooting measure. I'm doing so in part because when I run the diagnostics script it says the PETSC is not specified.

The test at the end of that article fails to build and returns this console output

try conda activate moose before running make

Ahh yeah, the diagnostic script needs some TLC (and its getting it! #26843).
The future script will not contain such misdirection :) Sorry for the confusion!

Here is the console output for attempting to make the test file in the proper enviroment.
(moose) calebfowler@DESKTOP-MV1434Q:~/mooseWorkspace/moose/test$ make -j 6
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/calebfowler/mooseWorkspace/moose/framework/build/unity_src/postprocessors_Unity.C...

make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

you are running out of memory. -j6 needs like 20GB of RAM
-j2 maybe?

It has taken a while to run through all the tests (and its still going), but the far majority of them have passed. There were quite a few however, that failed on timeout. Notably, this included a number of tests that mentioned skew correction. Also, I never saw more than two time steps printed in postprocessor values. During the tests, my system was using about 11/16 GB of RAM, so I'm not sure whether my machine's limits are to be blamed. All test failures have been
due to timeout.
Yeah your machine is dying a little if you timeout on the test suite. It s WSL's fault as well, slowing it down.

Just reading through the entire thread, be sure you are doing the following things before anything else MOOSE related:
module purge
module load apps site/tinkercliffs/easybuild/setup
module load apps site/tinkercliffs-rome/easybuild/setup
module load OpenMPI CMake
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
mamba activate python-stack
It looks like PETSc disappeared from your environment. You may have built all the support libraries, but then have not yet re-built the application.
When you do this:
[emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ git checkout master
Branch master set up to track remote branch master from origin.
Switched to a new branch 'master'
...or most anything git related, you'll then need to do this:
cd moose/scripts
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
./update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh
And when ever you do the above, you now need to also do this (clean and rebuild the application):
cd moose
git clean -xfd
cd test
make

Yeah I always load the environment with this before anything
module purge
module load apps site/tinkercliffs/easybuild/setup
module load apps site/tinkercliffs-rome/easybuild/setup
module load OpenMPI CMake
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
mamba activate python-stack
Since PETSc is not working again, what do I start with?

The issues I had some months ago that made me install the MOOSE this way with your instruction form your team was because I could not get a new CMake that works for my cluster. If I get that can I install MOOSE the conventional way as shown on the moose website?

node.title: Guidance on Derivatives for Concentration-Based Density Equation
node.bodyText:
I'm currently in the process of developing my own PorousFlow material and aiming to incorporate a concentration-based density equation for water. Initially, I'm considering a straightforward relation:
ρ=1000+0.001×C
Where 1000 represents the density of pure water, and C denotes concentration. However, I'm encountering difficulties in accurately determining the derivatives, I am using as a base PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid.C, and looks like there the derivatives are computed by an external function... Could someone provide guidance on how the derivatives should be computed?
to the code
Thanks,

Hi @burritotukituki
PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid doesn't propagate the derivatives towards the kernel.
You should have a look into PorousFlowMulticomponentFluid
and into PorousFlowBrine
Those objects call FluidProperties including a concentration variable. You can follow their structure and the structure in BrineFluidProperties to create your own FluidProperties object.
wops... looks more complicated than what I had in mind. Okay, thanks. I will take a look and come back to you.

Hi @1runer,
I've been delving into how these fluid properties function. From what I've gathered, it seems I need to create a C++ object similar to BrineFluidProperties.C. Within this object, there's a function called rho_from_p_T_X, which appears to be what I need...
Now, I can take this function as a starting point to develop my own. Water density is determined by rho_from_p_T, while the brine density is calculated by scaling the water density with the ratio of brine molar mass to pure water molar mass.
So, by modifying the brine density function and tailoring it to my requirements, it should work, right?

Yes. This should work.
But take care to also calculate the derivatives w.r.t. to the mass fraction.
You can do this either by your self or follow the approach in BrineFluidProperties using the AD formulation.

node.title: Re-installing MOOSE Conda environment: Installation taking 1hr+ to solve environment
node.bodyText:
I am re-installing the MOOSE conda environment following the steps described online (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html). I am re-installing MOOSE to try to resolve the issue that I have brought up in this discussion post (link: #26884).
However, I am noticing that conda has taken over an hour to try to 'solve the environment'. I have pasted the terminal output below:
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.01.23
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: /

Can anyone help me speed up the re-installation process via conda?

Hello
You need to update conda first, to get the new dependency resolver.
conda update conda

then it should run a lot faster, and you can conda update all then download moose-dev
Thanks! Do you know how many GB of internet these updates will use?
no i dont. Though conda will use cached (already downloaded) packages when it can iirc

This is the output that I get when I try conda update conda:
(base) enk001@drift-ph:~$ conda update conda
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: / 
The environment is inconsistent, please check the package plan carefully

  - conda-forge/linux-64::abseil-cpp==20211102.0=h93e1e8c_3
  - conda-forge/linux-64::libabseil==20211102.0=cxx17_h48a1fff_3
  - defaults/linux-64::_anaconda_depends==2024.02=py311_mkl_1
  - conda-forge/noarch::streamlit==1.31.1=pyhd8ed1ab_0
  - conda-forge/noarch::dask==2024.2.0=pyhd8ed1ab_0
failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): | WARNING conda.models.version:get_matcher(542): Using .* with relational operator is superfluous and deprecated and will be removed in a future version of conda. Your spec was 1.6.0.*, but conda is ignoring the .* and treating it as 1.6.0
WARNING conda.models.version:get_matcher(542): Using .* with relational operator is superfluous and deprecated and will be removed in a future version of conda. Your spec was 1.8.0.*, but conda is ignoring the .* and treating it as 1.8.0
WARNING conda.models.version:get_matcher(542): Using .* with relational operator is superfluous and deprecated and will be removed in a future version of conda. Your spec was 1.9.0.*, but conda is ignoring the .* and treating it as 1.9.0
WARNING conda.models.version:get_matcher(542): Using .* with relational operator is superfluous and deprecated and will be removed in a future version of conda. Your spec was 1.7.1.*, but conda is ignoring the .* and treating it as 1.7.1
done
Solving environment: / 

It seems there are 9 packages that are causing an 'inconsistent' base environment:  pyarrow-hotfix, pyarrow, grpc-cpp, arrow-cpp, abseil-cpp, libabseil, _anaconda_depends, streamlit and dask. Should I try updating these packages individually and then retry conda update conda? Or remove some combination of them and retry conda update conda?

I would delete the conda folder and re-install it.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html

I should mention that prior to installing MOOSE, I had the Anaconda distribution installed. I then followed the installation steps outlined online (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html), but in hindsight I don't think the MiniForge installation steps below really did anything given I already had conda installed via Anaconda:
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-Linux-x86_64.sh
bash Miniforge3-Linux-x86_64.sh -b -p ~/miniforge

export PATH=$HOME/miniforge/bin:$PATH

conda init --all
exit

But I made sure that I had the following channels activated nonetheless:
channels:
  - https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
  - conda-forge
  - defaults

Is this okay? I want to have Anaconda or Miniconda pre-installed as they offer a lot of packages that I can use in other environments (e.g. I have environments for training neural networks and doing other data-science things), and then I just want to create the additional 'moose' environment for MOOSE? Or is it vital to have MIniForge installed as recommended here:  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html?

Anaconda is fine, but you'll have to put up with Anaconda's very slow solver. This issue is why we moved away from Anaconda, to Miniforge.
If you neural network/data-science packages are available on conda-forge, then Miniforge can replace Anaconda. You can determine if that is the case by activating your neural/science environment, and performing a conda list. If you see a bunch of conda-forge, then you are good!

node.title: PorousFlow Density driven flow
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am interested in studying density-driven simulations. I thought a good starting point would be to utilize BrineFluidProperties with PorousFlow Brine. The concept involves mixing water with brine by maintaining a fixed pressure at a boundary.
I have a small model with water where I maintain a constant concentration of NaCl at the top. Please find my PF script attached.
https://github.com/burritotukituki/PF_concentration_density/tree/main
I've encountered difficulties in achieving convergence with this model. I'm unsure why the model isn't converging after a few time steps. Perhaps it's due to the density-driven flux resulting in small velocities that are challenging to simulate?
Any assistance or advice would be appreciated.

Hi,
I guess you are aware of the example of lava lamp?
Or in terms of temperature-driven convection of this example?
I would recommend to follow the example threating the mixture as 2phase - 2 component and solving individual equations for both phases. Convective mixing is highly sensitive to the mesh resolution. I think you should consider refining the mesh in the affected areas, either manually or using automatic mesh refinement (as shown in the examples above).
Yeah I based my simulation on those examples. I will take a second look, maybe I am missing something! Thanks

I haven't had a chance to check, but you might need to swap fluid_component indices in the kernels. When you pass Xnacl to the mass fraction material, you are saying that it is the mass fraction of fluid component 0 in phase 0, whereas you have it the other way around in your kernels.
Also, you should add diffusive kernels. Initially, mass transfer from the top boundary is via diffusion due to the gradient in mass fraction. As the instability grows, convective flux dominates and mass transfer is accelerated.
Thanks for your replies!! It worked when I changed the indices. Thanks!!

node.title: Use ADSideVectorDiffusiveFluxIntegral
node.bodyText:
I am attempting to use the following predefined postprocessor, ADSideVectorDiffusivityFluxIntegral, I am getting the following error shown bellow. What do I need to do to use this postprocessor?
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
No standard variable named velocity found. Did you specify a vector variable when you meant to specify a standard variable?

Hello
Hello
Could you please paste here your Variables and AuxVariables block, as well as the relevant postprocessor
Guillaume

I think what's happening is that you are trying to use this with a vector variable. But this postprocessor uses:

a regular variable, forms the gradient
an anisotropic diffusivity, which is the VectorDiffusive part of the name

and does the product with the normal to compute the diffusive flux
So if you want to use a velocity vector variable, you need to create a new postprocessor that uses a vector variable and does this operation component by component i imagine.
Guillaume

@GiudGiud , So it seems that I can define an aux variable vel_x from the x component of velocity. I could then use ADSideVectorDiffusivityFluxIntegral or similar to get the solution of the intergral of the following mu*(d(vel_x)/dxn_x+d(vel_x)/dyn_y)?
Yes. (d(vel_x)/dxn_x+d(vel_x)/dyn_y) = grad_vel_x * normal
but if mu is not a vector, you dont need the ADSideVECTORDiffusivityFluxIntegral. just use the regular one
Is there a predefined way to get  mu*(d(vel_x)/dxn_x+d(vel_y)/dyn_x)?
not that I know
@GiudGiud Thanks for the continued assistance. Let me know if you think of something novel to solve this problem.
@GiudGiud Where in the MOOSE code is _normals defined?

In the base class, if you look at line 40 of SideUserObject
    _normals(_assembly.normals()),

node.title: The meaning of solver parameter 'l-tol'
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I want to know the definition of parameter l-tol in [Executioner].
For example, when solving $Ax=b$, then l-tol = ${||b-Ax||} \over {||b-Ax_0||}$ ?, or l-tol = ${||b-Ax||} \over {||b||}$ ?
Thanks in advance!

Hello
l_tol is relative.
This question has a lot of nuances. You should complement this by looking the PETSc documentation for the solve_type of interest
Guillaume
Thanks for your suggestion! I have got the answer I want in the PETSc documentation-Krylov Methods-Convergence Tests .

node.title: How to reset sub-app data after each time step of main app in a Multi app simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm attempting to run a multi-app simulation that includes a full sub-app solution at each time step of the main app. My issue is figuring out how to reset sub-app data after each time step of the main app.
I noticed that the sub-model resumes the analysis from the previous time step of the main model, which contradicts my demand for a fresh start after each time step.
Moreover, when I attempted to use reset_ apps and rest_time, I received "Segmentation fault (core dumped)".
How can I reset sub-app data after each time step of the main app?
And this is the Multi app
`[MultiApps]
  [full_solve]
    type = FullSolveMultiApp
    input_files = Nucleation.i
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
    positions =  '0 0 0'
    no_backup_and_restore = true
    reset_apps = '0'
    reset_time = '5.0'

  [../]
[]`

Hello
You dont need the reset time / app parameter, just set the booleans to get a reset and you ll get a reset every time.
I think there's another one, not just no_backup_and_restore
Guillaume

I'm not sure what you mean by "set the booleans."
I eliminated the reset time / app parameter, as well as the no backup and restore option. Yet, the sub-app continues to use the previous iteration value, as follows:
[MultiApps]
  [full_solve]
    type = FullSolveMultiApp
    input_files = Nucleation.i
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  [../]
[]

set keep_solution_during_restore = false see if it helps
no_backup_and_restore = true should also be there
It had no effect.

Do you think the source code ( MultiApp.C )  is working properly?
Could you please take a kind look at the relevant source code  MultiApp.C  at https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/multiapps/MultiApp.C, line 638 to 713 to make sure it is working correctly for the TIMESTEP_BEGIN
Moreover, there is a topic (#18549) with a similar problem.
Thanks for your support,
Sajjad
I ll try to have a look today
Many Thanks,

ok so resetting (reset_time/app) does not work with FullSolveMultiApp.
I ll create an issue.

ok so we just do not have a clean mechanism to reset a FullSolveMultiApp at this point
reset is not working, and the backup/restore things are meant for fixed point iterations, not time step to time step.
HOWEVER, what you can do:

for auxvariables, use an auxkernel on initial to reset them to their initial condition:

[AuxKernels]
  [zero_out]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = u
    expression = 0 # could be the initial condition instead
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN # initial would be better but that does not work. Keep in mind this will run a LOT
  []
[]


for main variables, use a transfer from the parent app

[AuxVariables]
  [zero]
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [reset]
    type = MultiAppNearestNodeTransfer
    to_multi_app = sub
    source_variable = 'zero'  # this could be the initial condition for that variable instead
    variable = v # main variable to reset
  []

Hello Guillaume @GiudGiud,
thanks for your answer 'For main variables, use a transfer from the parent app'. It helps me solve the zero setting of one main variable.
But I have another sub-app main variable (i.e., pore pressure) reset to hydrostatic values (e.g., p=p0+rhogh increasing with depth)  at a specific time.
It works well if their mesh are same or at least has the same vertical extension scale. But in my case, the sub-app extent is from 0 to 500m depth. The main app only extends from 400m to 500m depth.

Only the p in their intersecting /overlapping areas (400-500 depth) have the same value to reference hydrostatic values.

Hello
So you want the field in the subapp to be reset even though its mesh extends beyond the one in the main app?
I think you could do this with siblings transfer.
Duplicate the multiapp for the subapp. Except one is inactive (just execute it on initial) and does not do anything, just act as a source for fields.
[MultiApps]
  [true_subapp]
   ...
  []
  [inactive_one]
    type = ...
    execute_on = INITIAL
    cli_args = 'Problem/solve=false'
    ...
  []
[]

then transfer from the inactive one to the real one
[Transfers]
  [sibling_pore_p]
    type = MultiAppGeneralFieldShapeEvaluationTransfer
    from_multiapp = inactive_one
    to_multiapp = true_subapp
    from_variable = pore_pressure
    to_variable = pore_pressure
  []
[]
Thanks for your answer. It works well for my problem. Have a nice weekend!
